possibleAnswers.text: Define it in the services.yaml file

question: What does the Dependency Injection component in Symfony manage ?

possibleAnswers.text: Annotations or YAML/attributes in routes configuration

question: What Symfony feature is designed to secure requests ?
What is the purpose of a Voter in Symfony Security ?

possibleAnswers.text: To manage CSRF protection for forms
To decide whether a user has permission for a specific action

question: Which service handles authentication in Symfony ?
What is the purpose of the Console component in Symfony ?

possibleAnswers.text: To create and manage console commands
To handle HTTP requests in CLI environments

question: Which service handles CSRF protection in Symfony ?
We downloaded a symfony binary during this chapter. Which of the following is most true?

possibleAnswers.text: It's a binary that... sort of doesn't have anything to do with Symfony, except that it has a command to help download a new Symfony project.
It's a binary that contains Symfony and is able to create new projects that link back to it.

question: Which of the following are valid ways to create a new Symfony project?

possibleAnswers.text: Both C and A are correct.

question: Which of the following is NOT true:

possibleAnswers.text: The src/ directory holds (pretty much) all the PHP code you'll write.
The vendor/ directory holds all the 3rd-party library code.
The public/ directory holds all 'public' PHP files that you create for different pages.
The config/ directory holds configuration files.

question: What must every controller function return?

possibleAnswers.text: A string type or Stringable object
A template string or a Response.
You "can" have an argument named $username in your profile() method... but it's not required.
You must have an argument named exactly $username in your profile() method.
You "can" have an argument with any name in your profile() method... but it must be the first argument.
You are allowed to have an argument with any name in your profile() method: the first argument will receive the {username} value if it exists.
It varies based on the flags passed to render()
The string HTML from the rendered template.

question: Which of these lines is NOT correct Twig syntax?
Which of the following is a correct Twig syntax to loop over an array?

Check out the following template:

{% extends 'base.html.twig' %}
< h1 >What will happen?< / h1 >
Where, inside of base.html.twig, will that < h1 > tag be rendered?

possibleAnswers.text: It will be rendered at the bottom of the base.html.twig template.
It will be rendered inside of the <body> tag.
Because it's not surrounded in a {% block %}, it will be rendered inside of the default body block.
It won't! Twig will panic and give you a big error!
The page will render like normal, but with the banana block appended to the bottom of the page, since it wasn't rendered anywhere else.
The page will render like normal, but the content of the banana block won't be displayed anywhere.
An error, because Twig will not be able to figure out where to render the <h1> tag.

question: What will happen if you call the dump() function inside a PHP file without any arguments?

possibleAnswers.text: An error will be thrown: "At least one argument is required"
Nothing much, this call will be just ignored, i.e. it returns an empty result and the script execution continues
It will print all known variables available at the line where it was called

question: After running composer require to install a Symfony "pack", how many new libraries will you have in your app?

possibleAnswers.text: None: a pack is an "empty" library that exists just to trigger a recipe.
You'll have one new entry in composer.json for each library that the pack requires (but you won't have the actual pack itself there)
You'll only have 1 new entry in your composer.json file, but because a pack requires other libraries, it will actually install as many libraries as the pack requires.

question: Suppose we are working on a Twig template and we need to add a CSS link to a checkout.css file that lives at public/css/. How would you do that?

Suppose I have a simple controller that extends Symfony\Bundle\FrameworkBundle\Controller\AbstractController. This time, in one of its actions, I want to return a JSON response instead of HTML. What would the return statement look like?
Check out this route: #[Route('/api/articles/{id}')]. How could we best guarantee that the {id} part of the URL is a number?
Which of the following is a valid way to get the "logger" service from inside a controller method?

possibleAnswers.text: Both A and C are correct.
Neither A nor C are correct.

question:
Because we like dinosaurs, I've created the following file:

// assets/dinosaur.js

console.log('RAAWR ðŸ¦–');
Scary! Assuming we have a standard Encore setup, how could we get this code to run on our page?

possibleAnswers.text: Update webpack.config.js to have this line: ".addEntry('dinosaur', './assets/dinosaur.js')"
It's automatic! Any JavaScript in the assets/ directory will be included when calling encore_entry_script_tags('app').

The HTML will not change at all:
Lucky Number
That's because hello-controller.js is an invalid name. It should be hello_controller.js.
